titleStmt.title: Wedding in Former Times Harran

monogr.title: A Digital Dictionary of Shawi Arabic

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the teiCorpusHeader prefix are pointers to any element in the SHAWI teiCorpus document.
Private URIs using the share prefix are pointers to audio file residing on the SHAWI network share.
Private URIs using the geo prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a place element in VICAV Geodata list.
Private URIs using the zotid prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a biblStruct element in the TEI export of the VICAV Zotero Group library.
Private URIs using the dict prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a entry in the SHAWI glossary.
Private URIs using the rend prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a rendition element in VICAV rendition library.

spanGrp.span: Let us also talk about the wedding. We have already talked about the death, so let us now also talk about the ṣubḥa (the celebration on the morning following the wedding).
Let me talk about the ṣubḥa. I want to talk about the people in former times; I am not talking about the later ones. Let’s say, people from former times, let’s say, we…
We, I mean, about ourselves; let’s say when we got my brother married, for example. When we got my brother married we first went to see the girl.
We liked her. We had already known her as she happens to be my aunt’s daughter, the girl.
And we said, “If this one wants to come, she should come with us. This should come with us.”
We had a brother; we had a brother. He was my brother but he was crippled. He could neither eat with his hands nor walk nor… He was crippled; his age was eighteen.
So we said, “Let’s go and bring, let’s take my cousin, because this is better than…
Let us take a relative, let us take my cousin.”
So we took her. How much did her father ask from us? She is my cousin, but her father is a stranger; he is from another tribe, he is a man from the Ḥbēṭ tribe.
He wanted fifty milliards from us as dowry. And this in former times; fifty millions, fifty millions, yes!
My dowry was sixty and hers was fifty millions. Because she was a little bit closer, there was kinship; so, my dowry surpassed hers.
The dowry of Maḥmūd’s Ǧamīle surpassed ours and my dowry surpassed hers. One by one, I mean, the three of us left (home) at the same time.
I mean, within two months all three of us left (home).
Then we went; my family got her engaged, they gave her (to them) and they also wanted to give her to my family; to my family.
I mean they are well off, their situation is is good and their room will be a nice room for their daughter.
So they gave her (to them) and within a week everything was over. My word! There was no engagement for two or three months, nothing! – No!
As soon as they said, “Alright, brother, read the Fātiḥa for her!”, the men went out. Let’s say, the one who wants to go and ask for her hand.
At first, the women go and when they say, “Alright!” When the women accept it the girl accepts it as well.
Then the men go there. The men agree on the dowry, the trousseau and the gold.
They agree on everything, they recite the Fāthiḥa for her and then they come back.
They chat with each other and then the girl’s father, after he has taken the dowry, he goes away with the dowry.
Let’s say, they all were mad on wool.
They only had wool in their minds, so they immediately went. And how much did they buy? A ton, a ton and a half; wool, wool. – A ton and a half? – Yes, a ton and a half!
As for Amīne, Ismāʕīl’s sister, they bought a ton and eight hundred kilos of wool for her.
Her father went ahead and came to the city here just to buy wool.
After he had brought the wool, the women started with the wedding thing (i.e. preparations).
Then they started to wash the wool by clomping (on it); then they hung it up and brought the tickings (for the mattresses and blankets).
Some people were sitting on the machine, on the sewing machines. The did the sewing; the one who knows how to sew was on the machine.
Some people did the cutting. The one who knows it and who has skills. The one whose mind can adjust to everything.
“Sister! How large a quilt should we make?” Someone says, “Make…!”
Let’s say (large), since it is a bride’s quilt and since a bride’s quilt and a (normal) home’s quilt are not the same. Don’t they want to show it off to people? I mean it’s a thing!
When they later show it (to the people) they would say, “Wow! How big the quilt is! How big the mattress is, how big the pillow is!” Therefore they make it two meters long.
And like that, let’s say, they make the quilt two spans long, and they make the width the same size.
They cut it then, some people start tailoring and some do the sewing. Then they bring the wool and arrange it.
They hit it. They stay occupied the whole time with the wool. For a whole week they are busy with the wool.
Until the weekend he can take it. Until the week is over, they say, “Sister!” Then they give it away, they call the groom’s family.
The groom (family) does not think about it. They only give and deliver the dowry but then they do not interfere in anything.
They step aside and do not interfere in anything. The bride’s family are the ones who must deal with it.
And then they also call them, “Sister! Aren’t you done? I want it until this and that day; until Monday we want to go to buy the trousseau.”
To (buy) the suit for the groom. “Okay, brother, we are done!”
They discuss it and then they get into a car.
If those then have a car, the bride’s family.
Each of them agree on it on the phone. And if the bride’s family does not have (a car), the groom’s family comes and picks the bride’s family up.
I mean, they make an agreement among each other before they ride to the city here.
They come here to the city; to our market here, the city’s market, to the clothes market.
How much have they previously agreed on for the dowry? They said, let’s say, eight dresses, seven dresses of these Arab costumes.
Among them colourful, gleaming, glittering and plain ones.
They always aim for the most expensive ones so that the groom’s family will be ruined (literally: that they destroy their house).
They aim for those ones that cost three hundred million, four hundred, five hundred. Just one dress!
They do not let the groom buy something cheap; it’s a sin (that they don’t feel sorry for him). No! Everything must be from the most expensive kinds!
They only take from the expensive ones. And they start to argue, how not!
They quarrel; for sure they quarrel; they argue at buying the trousseau, for sure!
Everyone says this… However, if the father (of the girl) really wants… my late father (for example) did not argue.
He would say, “Let them buy how much they want!
Hey, it’s anyway for us! It’s for us!” He would say, “Whatever the women buy, whatever they buy, it is for us.
These clothes are coming to us anyway, so don’t quarrel. Or are you stupid?
We would say, “No! They should take (from the expensive things), because they do not spend too much money.”

The families of… They argue inside the store of the thingy, inside the clothes store. Afterwards, who is the one (F) who comes as a stranger? [as also women of the extended family want to get new clothes]
Let’s say, I mean, not (really) strange, but as I said, I mean, like me, I am coming if the bride’s maternal aunt is coming or if the bride’s paternal aunt or the groom’s aunt is coming.
It is the groom’s father, it is always the groom’s father who has to pay.
He goes ahead then and buys a dress saying, “Sister, make a dress also for this one and another for that one!”
For those strange women who attend the buying of the trousseau (he says), “Make a dress also for this one!” They let make dresses for them too.
After they have had dresses made for them, they say, “Sisters, let’s go!”
If they do not have a house or someone to stay at, they say, “Let’s go, sister, to the restaurant!” That’s their tradition.
Then the groom’s father offers lunch for all of them. The women are on one side and the men are on the other side.
So he offers them lunch at the restaurant and then they take a car and bring the clothes; they deliver them to the tailor.
And then they buy a dress for the bride. Now, is the bride tall or short?
Is she very short? How is she, the bride? Fat? Thin? For sure!
They bring a piece of her clothes (as a model), because it would be a shame (if she came in person). The bride cannot come and has a dress tailored.
I mean, we are Arabs who bring a piece of her clothes and give it to the tailor.
They say, “Brother, tailor it according to this one!” Then the tailor measures it, cuts it, and then gives them their dress.
One of them cuts them and then the tailor starts sewing them.
And they say, “Brother, take care of our order immediately! I mean, you will have it done this week, won’t you?
Because our wedding is already next week.”
They make their request at the tailor, and the tailor then sews it and prepares their trousseau in time.
They go on then and not only here. They ruin the groom’s family not only with dresses.
But also, with those black headdresses called ṭōn, one hundred fifty million each; (they take) two to three of them.
Four or five of these white headdresses, shoes, socks, bracelets, scarfs.
Let’s say, one of these expensive scarfs. I do not know some of these sets which are put on the bed sheets. I do not know what else.
They take, I mean, stuff, handicraft products other than the clothes.
I mean, buying the trousseau is not only that; there is also the gold which they buy as a trousseau.
According to how much they have agreed on, let’s say, five (gold) liras for the bride. So, the groom’s father goes ahead and lets make them (as a necklace).
He gives them either on the henna day or he gives them when buying the clothes.
He says, “These are your liras, brother, so they can put them on her.” They put them then on the bride.
As for her family, haven’t they taken the dowry? I mean they have already taken the dowry.
As for her family, it is up to them. They give according to their standards, it is up to their prestige.
Let’s say, it is then up to her family. The issue comes now on her family.
Her family, if they were a good family and if they want comforts for their daughter, they go ahead and put more than fifty million.
They put money, I mean, they increase it, let’s say, they buy some of the good sideboards.
They buy good carpets as we are also those who receive the dowry.
The bride’s father does not take the dowry (for himself).
Didn’t the groom’s father give a dowry? But the bride’s father does not take the dowry for himself.
He takes the dowry and comes to the city. Separately, not with the groom’s family, just he alone.
He comes then and prepares the trousseau for his daughter. He takes the white goods.
What are the white goods? The washing machine, the dishwasher, I mean, nowadays.
And the gas cooker and the stove and whatever there is not yet here.
I mean, he buys the sideboard, the fridge and the television set. And even the air conditioning nowadays.
I mean, didn’t he take the dowry? He buys curtains, carpets, pillows, mattrasses for sitting.
Everything. Whatever comes to your mind. Everything in the house, even the satellite dish,
even the satellite dish, the living-room suite, the… I mean, a complete house, a complete household, absolutely!
Even the iron, the table, the armchairs,… I mean, a house, how is a house built?
The house gets built until there is a stove and the needle and the thread – Even the electric stove.
Master, even the needle and the thread, absolutely everything that comes to your mind.
He even buys a sack of sugar. – Nothing remains in his hands. – Even a kilo of tea. – Does anything remain from the dowry in his hands?
Even a sack of sugar, even tea. So his daughter does not have to ask her (new) family when she has been gone (to her new home).
My people are ignorant, yes. Some of them fill up even the washing powder, even the soap.
Some of them even bring (things) and fill up, let’s say, their daughter’s chests.
They put pistachios, walnuts, ‘fruit leather’ and biscuits for (eating) at night.
(The bride’s mother says,) “I am afraid that when she goes there, she becomes shy and does not eat food for a week.”
So she can still eat what her heart desires after she has come to her new family. She can eat a little bit by going to her room.
She keeps eating biscuits and sugar until she gets full. – Doesn’t the bride eat a lot?
In her chest there is everything for her daily bread. – She eats only a little. – At her new family’s she eats only a little (because of respect and fear).
But maybe she is not full. Therefore, they put food for her as backup.
As backup, yes. They put dried fruits for her. Later then, they prepare her trousseau.Ismāʕīl: But why did you not bring any (when we married)?
I will talk about that later. – Okay. – Later because now he is recording.
Afterwards then, when the trousseau is ready, when it is done; they have prepared their trousseau.
And the suit for the groom; and after they also have prepared the house, they call each other on the phone.
Saying, “Brother, we want to come on the henna day to take the clothes.” The groom’s family brings them.
They bring them by renting a car, a truck. And all their people gather because they have already sent invitation letters.
Around fifty or sixty men gather for the wedding. All their relatives. And they have started to make a dabče (dance) and drums are being played.
They put the drum (on the truck) and then they go and keep hanking the horn and playing drums till they reach the house of the bride’s family.
They come and bring those utensils, the quilts which are ready. The quilts; ten quilts and ten pillows and ten matresses.
There are so many utensils coming that the car cannot take them because of their sheer quantity.
A full household, I mean, it is like moving a whole house. They bring it then and come to the groom’s house.
They start unloading them on the henna day. They unload them and the clothes, but they keep one dress at bride’s place.
Saying, “Sister, these are for you to wear on the day you come.” I mean like a wedding dress.
They leave one dress at her place, together with its belt, the socks and all its things.
They also leave a pair of her shoes; they leave one dress and then bring all the rest to the groom’s family; all her clothes.
And then they put her house in order. The groom’s family arrange everything and provide for her one or two rooms.
It depends then on their standards, on the prestige of the groom’s family.
Then there is also the celebration on the morning after the wedding (ṣubḥa). The ṣubḥa was held in former times. They would bring pots (of food) if the groom’s father was in a good mood and happy.
Nowadays, because everybody has become lazy, he just would slaughter an animal at night.
He would slaughter then some animals, let’s say, he has invited a lot of people, so he needs three or four animals.
Some of them even slaughter an ox, yes, an ox!
They would slaughter it at night. They would not sleep the whole night, the groom’s family.
At the henna night, the people send a car to make the henna at the bride’s family.
A car to go and do the henna to the bride. They apply henna while the bride’s family have already gathered their neighbours.
Then they are applying the henna on themselves. Then a car comes from the groom’s family; one single car comes.
Then he makes henna to the bride and gives her a Kemāli (gold coin). He puts it in her hands, does the henna to her and goes back.
And these then, the groom’s family have been busy, especially the groom’s mother.
Whether his brothers’ families or his sisters’. They are bringing (animals) to slaughter and cut them and they are preparing from the night before onwards.
They are preparing until the morning. When they wake up they start cooking to be ready for the thingy, the ṣubḥa.
Yes, from the night before they get done at once, with the thing of the meat, the issue of the meat.
And at night, if they want to have something in [their stomach],
they roast the liver for themselves; those ones who have got tired from work.
They stay; they stay the night awake until the morning, until sunrise. They do not sleep that day.
They go ahead then and start to wake up in the morning. What should they do? Let’s say, they want to make bulgur and stew.
Let’s say, a stew or green beans; whatever they are cooking.
And they bring, let’s say, the pots, they arrange the pots and put the meat in them. A pot of meat.
And they bring and put a pot of bulgur or rice and then they put a pot of green beans.
Let’s say, they want to make (food); they have brought it from the city, they have already bought it.
They have bought three or four sacks of green beans and the women have been sitting together, let’s say, either the groom’s paternal aunts or the female relatives or his sisters.
They start to cut the green beans; some cut the garlic and some others peel the tomatoes.
And that man (the chef) oversees them and the grandmothers also supervise them.
He roasts the thin noodles for the bulgur, he roasts the noodles and pours them… he boils the water in another pot.
And then pours the water on it, he comes back to the bulgur and puts it on a light fire and so the food becomes cooked.
And the meat is then cooked in another pot. Then he brings the beans in the same way and puts the meat to it separately.
And he brings the beans and puts it on them and then he adds the tomatoes.
And he puts the molasses on it, he adds water and garlic, salt and its thing; all at once to complete it.
Then the chili pepper and now he puts it again on a light fire.

They also start cooking, some people. The food there is getting ready until it is time. They keep looking at the clock until the time has come. (The time) on which they have agreed on with the bride’s family. When? At 11 o’clock they will make the wedding procession of their bride.
They have given a certain time. When they go around and when there is show-off. In former times they used to send fifteen cars, they used to send many (and so) accidents happened.

In former times they used to send twenty or thirty cars, they would even send an invitation to everybody who has a car so that he would come and shows a car. So it would happen that (people say), “Man, there came thirty cars to pick up the daughter of so-and-so.” Isn’t it like that?”
But nowadays, people are getting afraid of the traffic accidents, they are afraid of the thing and so they send only one car which picks up the bride and comes back.

When they then bring the food it has getting cold. They bring then the plates and the groom’s mother goes and collects utensils. She gathers utensils from all (the neighbours) around her who have some.

Then they start to cool down the food and then they serve it to the people who have come to them. Those who have come to the wedding procession. Then they also serve lunch; they serve the lunch and after they had lunch the people disperse. The people go away an they bring then their bride home. That’s it. Enjoy it!
